description.summary: Generic European nightmare spirit from which the word 'nightmare' derives. A spirit entity that 'rides' sleepers at night, sitting on the chest to cause bad dreams, suffocation sensations, and sleep paralysis.
description.full: The Mare is the generic European term for nightmare spirits found across Germanic, Slavic, and Scandinavian cultures. The English word 'nightmare' literally means 'night-mare'—a night visit from the Mare spirit, not referring to a female horse. This entity is believed to sit on or 'ride' sleeping victims like a horse, oppressing their breathing and inducing terrifying dreams and paralysis. Across European folklore, the Mare can manifest as a demonic entity or, in some traditions, as the involuntarily wandering soul of a living person. Folk beliefs held that the Mare could be trapped by securing the suspected person's body, preventing their spirit from wandering. Protection methods included iron objects, horseshoes, plugging keyholes to prevent entry, and Christian symbols. The Mare represents one of the most widespread and linguistically influential folklore entities, with variants appearing across nearly all European cultures as a cultural interpretation of the universal human experience of sleep paralysis.

etymology.origin: From Proto-Germanic *marōn, from Proto-Indo-European *mor- (to rub away, harm)
etymology.meaning: The spirit that rides or oppresses during sleep
etymology.note: NOT related to 'mare' meaning female horse—coincidental homonym in English

related_phenomena.name: Incubus/Succubus
related_phenomena.description: Sometimes conflated with Mare in folklore

appearance.description: Feels extremely heavy when sitting on chest
Sense of malevolent entity in room

physical.nature: Can be demonic entity or wandering soul of living person, depending on regional tradition

abilities.description: Sits on or 'rides' victims like riding a horse
Creates crushing weight sensation on chest
Oppresses breathing, creates sensation of being smothered

behavior.attack_pattern: Visits during sleep, particularly those sleeping on backs
behavior.double_nature: Can be external demon OR wandering soul of living person (tradition-dependent)

soul_wandering.description: In some traditions, the Mare is the soul of a living person that leaves the body involuntarily at night
identification: May sweat or appear disheveled upon waking
soul_wandering.trap_method: Securing or confining the suspected person's body prevents their soul from wandering

demonic_entity.description: In other traditions, the Mare is an independent evil spirit or demon
demonic_entity.nature: External malevolent entity seeking to torment sleepers

preventive_measures.description: Iron under pillow or near bed repels Mare
Plug keyholes, seal openings to prevent Mare entry
Place shoes with toes pointing away from bed
Mare must count broom straws, delaying until dawn

trapping.description: If Mare is believed to be a person's wandering soul, physically confining that person prevents wandering

range.description: Pan-European phenomenon with variants across Germanic, Slavic, Scandinavian, and other European cultures

origins.cultural_roots: Ancient European folk traditions dating to pre-Christian times
origins.earliest_accounts: Indo-European traditions, formalized in medieval texts
origins.folklore_connections: Related to worldwide sleep paralysis entity traditions

linguistic_evolution.modern_meaning: Bad dream (supernatural entity meaning lost in common usage)
linguistic_evolution.preservation: The word 'nightmare' preserves ancient folklore in modern language

etymology_detail.not_a_horse: Despite modern confusion, 'mare' in 'nightmare' does NOT refer to a female horse. This is a coincidental homonym in English.

scientific_explanation.interpretation: The Mare represents European cultural interpretation of sleep paralysis, a universal human physiological phenomenon
scientific_explanation.sleep_paralysis: The sensation of chest pressure, inability to move, and hallucinations during sleep-wake transitions were interpreted as a spirit 'riding' the sleeper
scientific_explanation.universality: Sleep paralysis affects all human populations; nearly every culture developed similar explanatory entities
scientific_explanation.status: Traditional folklore explaining well-documented medical phenomenon

folklore.role: Primary European explanation for sleep paralysis and nightmares
folklore.cultural_sensitivity: Important part of European folk heritage across multiple cultures

linguistic_legacy.significance: One of the most successful folklore concepts to survive in modern language
linguistic_legacy.daily_usage: Billions of people use the word 'nightmare' without knowing its origin as a supernatural entity
linguistic_legacy.semantic_shift: Rare example of supernatural entity name becoming purely psychological term

sources.title: The Terror That Comes in the Night
